name: Static Fuzzy Search
description: This plugin provides website owners with an easy way to add a fuzzy search functionality to their site. By leveraging the feed.json and fuse.js javascript library, this plugin offers a fast and reliable search experience for users, without the need for a dynamic search engine. With this plugin, site owners can quickly and easily improve the user experience and help visitors find the information they need.
author: freaks-dev

messageInOptions.text: This is a third-party plugin and is not affiliated with Publii or Fuse.js. The search functionality in this plugin is powered by Fuse.js , a lightweight JavaScript library that enables fuzzy searching. The Fuse.js script is bundled within the plugin itself, meaning it is hosted alongside your website and no external requests are made. Before adjusting any search settings, please refer to the official Fuse.js documentation to understand the available configuration options. ⚙️ Setup Requirements: - Ensure that both "Search" and "Search subpage" options are enabled in your Theme settings under the Search tab. - Also, enable JSON Feed in Site Settings under the RSS/JSON Feed section. Without these settings enabled, the search feature will not function.

config.name: jsonFeedUrl
config.label: JSON Feed Url
config.note: Enter the URL to the JSON feed of your website.

config.name: searchParam
config.label: Search parameter
config.note: You can change the default "q" search parameter if desired; recommended only for advanced users.

config.name: isCaseSensitive
config.label: isCaseSensitive
config.note: Indicates whether comparisons should be case sensitive

config.name: ignoreDiacritics
config.label: ignoreDiacritics
config.note: Indicates whether comparisons should ignore diacritics (accents)

config.name: includeScore
config.label: includeScore
config.note: Whether the score should be included in the result set. A score of 0indicates a perfect match, while a score of 1 indicates a complete mismatch

config.name: includeMatches
config.label: includeMatches
config.note: Whether the matches should be included in the result set. When true, each record in the result set will include the indices of the matched characters. These can consequently be used for highlighting purposes

config.name: minMatchCharLength
config.label: minMatchCharLength
config.note: Only the matches whose length exceeds this value will be returned. (For instance, if you want to ignore single character matches in the result, set it to 2)

config.name: location
config.label: location
config.note: Determines approximately where in the text is the pattern expected to be found

config.name: threshold
config.label: threshold
config.note: At what point does the match algorithm give up. A threshold of 0.0 requires a perfect match (of both letters and location), a threshold of 1.0 would match anything

config.name: distance
config.label: distance
config.note: Determines how close the match must be to the fuzzy location (specified by location). An exact letter match which is distance characters away from the fuzzy location would score as a complete mismatch. A distance of 0 requires the match be at the exact location specified. A distance of 1000 would require a perfect match to be within 800 characters of the location to be found using a threshold of 0.8

config.name: shouldSort
config.label: shouldSort
config.note: Whether to sort the result list, by score

config.name: findAllMatches
config.label: findAllMatches
config.note: When true, the matching function will continue to the end of a search pattern even if a perfect match has already been located in the string

config.name: ignoreLocation
config.label: ignoreLocation
config.note: When true, search will ignore location and distance, so it won't matter where in the string the pattern appears. The default options only search the first 60 characters. This should suffice if it is reasonably expected that the match is within this range. To modify this behavior, set the appropriate combination of location, threshold, distance (or ignoreLocation). To better understand how these options work together, read Fuse.js Scoring Theory

config.name: useExtendedSearch
config.label: useExtendedSearch
config.note: When true, it enables the use of unix-like search commands. See example

config.name: ignoreFieldNorm
config.label: ignoreFieldNorm
config.note: When true, the calculation for the relevance score (used for sorting) will ignore the field-length norm

config.name: fieldNormWeight
config.label: fieldNormWeight
config.note: Determines how much the field-length norm affects scoring. A value of 0 is equivalent to ignoring the field-length norm. A value of 0.5 will greatly reduce the effect of field-length norm, while a value of 2.0 will greatly increase it
